# Day 1239

**Freedom to Transact: Tor, Bitcoin, and the Fight for Economic Privacy**

_By Conor Chepenik_

**February 2022, Ottawa.** A freezing dawn breaks over the Canadian capital as truckers protesting pandemic mandates wake to a nightmare: their bank cards are dead. At the stroke of a minister's pen, hundreds of ordinary Canadians found themselves locked out of their life savings, no court order, no due process, just algorithmic exile for donating to a cause their government opposed.

Some supporters rushed to Bitcoin, thinking they'd found a workaround. But without proper precautions, those transactions were traced within hours. In that brief, chilling episode, the Western world learned what Venezuelans, Nigerians, and Russians already knew: **financial surveillance can silence speech faster than any censor's red pen.**

This should both terrify and galvanize us. Money is so much more than just numbers on a screen. It is how we express our values, reward honest work, care for our families, and resist injustice. When the freedom to transact dies, every other freedom follows in its wake.

But here's the crucial part: **we already possess the digital tools to defend ourselves.** Two technologies, Bitcoin and Tor, were built for exactly this moment. Used together, they create something revolutionary: uncensorable money flowing through untraceable networks, forming the backbone of a parallel economy where privacy is the default, not a rare exception.

**The Death of Cash, The Birth of the Panopticon**

According to [a 2024 Mckinsey report](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/global-payments-in-2024-simpler-interfaces-complex-reality) "Global cash usage now stands at 80 percent of 2019 levels and continues to decrease at 4 percent a year." As tap-to-pay convenience spread like wildfire, so did something more sinister: a breathtaking data harvest that would make totalitarian regimes of the past weep with envy.

Every card swipe, every digital payment feeds ravenous corporate algorithms and government surveillance systems. They know who you meet, what you read, where you worship, what you believe. Beijing's social credit system made this model explicit: a digital panopticon where financial behavior determines social standing. Ottawa's trucker crackdown proved this dystopia can bloom anywhere, even in supposedly free societies.

Neither trend is accidental. Surveillance capitalism is extraordinarily profitable, and centralized money creates a chokepoint too tempting for any power structure to ignore.

That's why visionary cypherpunks in the 1990s began coding an alternative future: truly private communication through Tor, and bearer-style digital cash through Bitcoin. They understood a fundamental truth, privacy isn't secrecy, it's the basic right to choose what you reveal about yourself.

The beautiful irony is that governments themselves clearly understand the value of privacy. The U.S. Navy originally developed Tor to protect intelligence communications, and the NSA has long championed strong encryption for its own operations. When it comes to their own secrets, privacy suddenly becomes a matter of national security. Yet when citizens seek the same protections for their financial lives, those same tools are branded as instruments of criminality.

The message is clear: privacy for me, but not for thee. Surveillance for citizens, anonymity for the state. This double standard reveals everything about who really benefits from our current financial panopticon, and why citizens must build our way out of it.

**A Global Crackdown Already Underway**

The evidence is mounting across continents:

ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡¦  Canada, 2022: 206 bank accounts frozen overnight, $8 million trapped in bureaucratic limbo, donors doxxed and harassed. All without trial, all for supporting a peaceful protest.

ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡¬  Nigeria, 2020: When young people rose up in the #EndSARS movement, authorities weaponized the banking system against them. Donations pivoted to Bitcoin within days, keeping the movement alive.

ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡º  Russia, 2021-present: NGOs critical of Putin's regime lost access to traditional banking. They survived by accepting Bitcoin donations routed through Tor, staying operational despite state persecution.

ðŸ‡»ðŸ‡ª  Venezuela, ongoing: With hyperinflation exceeding 300% and suffocating capital controls, Bitcoin, often received through onion-routed remittances, has become a literal lifeline for millions of families.

Different continents, same playbook, same lesson: the mere possibility of financial punishment chills free speech and independent thought long before anyone gets arrested.

**Why Bitcoin Alone Falls Short (And Tor Can't Pay Your Bills)**

Bitcoin elegantly solves the "who gets to freeze the ledger?" problem. No central bank can print more. No payment processor can block transactions. No government can successfully blacklist wallets from transacting peer-to-peer. The mathematics are incorruptible.

Yet Bitcoin's transparency creates a new vulnerability: every transaction lives forever on a public ledger. Blockchain analysis firms like Chainalysis and Elliptic already sell detailed dossiers on "suspicious" wallet activities to law enforcement and corporate clients. After Canada's account freezes, analysts traced convoy donations within hours using these exact techniques. Unlike fiat donations some bitcoin still made it to the truckers, but it was by no means a silver bullet.

That's why Tor, the onion router network that conceals digital footprints behind layers of volunteer-run relays scattered across the globe, is so important. When your Bitcoin node connects through Tor, surveillance networks hit a mathematical wall. They can't tie transactions to your physical location, your internet provider, or your real identity.

But Tor alone can't solve the money problem. You can browse privately, but you still need a way to transact that doesn't depend on legacy financial rails.

The magic happens when you combine them: Tor blinds the network layer (who is talking to whom) while Bitcoin, used properly, obscures the transaction layer (who is paying whom). Together, they restore the essential properties of physical cash in digital form: permissionless, borderless, and genuinely private.

**Real-World Proof of Concept**

This is not a theoretical thing, people are using these technologies:

- Venezuelan families receive wages and remittances in Bitcoin over Tor, bypassing 50% government fees and capital control checkpoints that would otherwise trap their money.

- Russian independent media funds operations through Tor-only BTCPay servers that Kremlin censors simply cannot locate or block, no matter how hard they try.

- Nigerian developers invoice international clients via Lightning Network channels announced exclusively through Tor. The same USD wire transfers would trigger immediate banking flags and account freezes.

- Canadian trucker supporters who routed donations through Tor-enabled privacy tools like Whirlpool have faced zero account freezes, unlike those who donated through traditional, surveillable channels.

These aren't edge cases or criminal enterprises. Recent network analysis reveals that [over 60% of Bitcoin nodes now connect to the network through Tor](https://bitnodes.io/nodes/?q=Tor%20network%20(TOR)), hiding their locations and making the entire system more private. Lightning Network payments, already processing over a billion dollars annually, use onion-style routing by architectural design. The parallel financial system will continue to grow as the legacy system cracks down.

**The Window Is Narrowing Fast**

Governments worldwide are waking up to this threat. The [U.S. Treasury's 2022 sanctioning of Tornado Cash marked an unprecedented attack on open-source code itself](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0916), criminalizing mathematics and privacy tools. Draft Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) frameworks from Europe to India embed mandatory surveillance checkpoints into every digital wallet.

Meanwhile, internet service providers experiment with Tor blocking, and legislators float "lawful access" mandates that would backdoor all encryption. The surveillance state is adapting, learning, evolving.

If we want genuine financial privacy tomorrow, we must deploy and normalize these tools today.

**An Action Plan: Seven Steps to Financial Sovereignty**

1. Browse Privately by Default

Download Tor Browser and use it for sensitive searches, research, and donations. Make privacy your baseline, not an afterthought.

2. Run Your Own Bitcoin Node

One evening and a spare Raspberry Pi grants you complete sovereignty over your money while strengthening the entire network. Guide available at [https://bitcoin.org/en/full-node](https://bitcoin.org/en/full-node)

3. Choose Privacy-First Wallets

Bitcoin wallets like Wasabi, Sparrow, and others can route traffic through Tor and offer accessible coin-mixing features that break transaction linkability.

4. Embrace Lightning for Daily Spending

Move small, frequent purchases to Lightning Network wallets like Phoenix or Breez that default to Tor routing. Your morning coffee doesn't need a permanent blockchain footprint.

5. Buy Bitcoin Privately

Use peer-to-peer platforms like hodlhodl, robosats, bisq and others while leveraging Tor onion services to acquire bitcoin without invasive Know Your Customer requirements.

6. Fund the Fight

Donate to organizations defending digital rights, the Tor Project, Electronic Frontier Foundation, Human Rights Foundation, and do so using Bitcoin over Tor. Practice the principles while supporting the cause.

7. Educate Someone New

Privacy technologies gain strength through network effects. Every new user expands the anonymity set and makes the system more robust for everyone.

**This Is A Fight About Human Dignity**

Privacy opponents love deploying the tired "nothing to hide" clichÃ©. Try telling that to:

- The Venezuelan mother who kept her children fed through onion-routed remittances while her government's currency collapsed

- The Nigerian activist who stayed online and organized after traditional banks bowed to state pressure

- The Canadian father whose mortgage payments bounced because he donated $50 to support a peaceful protest

Economic privacy does not make you a criminal, it's the essential shield that allows lawful dissent to survive and thrive.

Our grandparents could hand cash to a stranger without asking anyone's permission, without generating permanent records, without algorithmic approval. We deserve that same fundamental freedom online. Privacy shouldn't change whether the medium is paper bills or cryptographic keys.

**Choose Your Future Or Others Will Choose It for You**

The alliance of Bitcoin and Tor is less than two decades old, yet it already underwrites the financial autonomy of millions across the world. If enough of us adopt these tools, regulators will think twice before automatically equating privacy with criminality, just as widespread HTTPS adoption killed legislative proposals to outlaw web encryption entirely.

But if we hesitate, if we assume someone else will fight this battle, the cashless surveillance panopticon will harden into place one silently blocked account at a time.

The freedom to transact is the bedrock of every free society. It enables all other freedoms, speech, association, religion, political participation. Without it, democracy becomes nothing more than a performative theater while real power flows through AI powered algorithmic financial chokepoints controlled by increasingly authoritarian institutions.

The tools exist. The networks are live. The only question is whether enough people will use them before it's too late. For the sake of your children's children, let's build the world they deserve.

Use these tools. Protect this freedom. Spread it until privacy becomes the default.

8/12/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
